fever.title: Fever Care Guide
fever.summary: Fever is the body's natural response to infection. Most fevers in children are caused by viral illnesses and resolve on their own.
when_to_call_911: Fever in infant under 3 months old (any fever)
Child is unresponsive or very difficult to wake
Child has purple or blood-red spots on skin that don't fade with pressure
when_to_call_now: Fever above 104°F (40°C)
Fever in infant 3-6 months old above 101°F (38.3°C)
Child looks very sick or is unusually drowsy
Stiff neck or severe headache
Child is not making tears when crying or has no wet diapers for 8+ hours
Child has had a febrile seizure (first time)
when_to_call_24_hours: Fever lasting more than 3 days
Fever between 102-104°F (38.9-40°C) in children over 3 months
Child has ear pain or sore throat
Child is not drinking well
Fever went away for 24+ hours then came back

general_advice: Keep your child comfortable - they don't need to 'sweat out' the fever
Dress in light clothing and use light blankets
Ensure they get plenty of rest
Push fluids - water, clear broths, popsicles, oral rehydration solutions

acetaminophen.when_to_use: For fever above 102°F (38.9°C) or if child is uncomfortable
acetaminophen.dosing: See dosage chart based on weight
warnings: Do not exceed 5 doses in 24 hours
Do not give to infants under 3 months without doctor approval

ibuprofen.when_to_use: Alternative to acetaminophen for children 6 months and older
ibuprofen.dosing: See dosage chart based on weight
warnings: Give with food to prevent stomach upset

what_not_to_do: Do not give aspirin to children (risk of Reye syndrome)
Do not use rubbing alcohol baths
Do not bundle up a child with fever
Do not alternate medications unless directed by a doctor
Do not wake a sleeping child just to give fever medicine

infant_0_3_months.critical_warning: ANY fever (100.4°F/38°C or higher) in a baby under 3 months requires IMMEDIATE medical evaluation. Go to the emergency room.
infant_0_3_months.reason: Young infants cannot fight infections well and can become very sick very quickly.

infant_3_6_months.warning: Call your doctor for any fever above 101°F (38.3°C) or if baby seems uncomfortable or unwell.

child_6_24_months.advice: Monitor closely. Call if fever lasts more than 24 hours or child seems very sick.

cough_cold.title: Cough and Cold Care Guide
cough_cold.summary: Most coughs and colds are caused by viruses and will get better on their own in 7-10 days. Antibiotics do not help viral infections.
when_to_call_911: Child is having severe difficulty breathing
Child's lips or face are turning blue
Child is making grunting sounds with each breath
Child is unresponsive or very difficult to wake
when_to_call_now: Child is breathing very fast or working hard to breathe
Nostrils flare with breathing or you can see ribs with each breath
Child cannot speak or cry normally due to breathing difficulty
Barking cough with noisy breathing (stridor) that doesn't improve with steam
Child is drooling and unable to swallow
Child under 3 months with any cough
when_to_call_24_hours: Cough lasting more than 2 weeks
Cough with fever lasting more than 3 days
Wheezing or whistling when breathing
Child has ear pain
Yellow or green nasal discharge for more than 10 days
Cough keeping child from sleeping

general_advice: Encourage rest and plenty of fluids
Use a cool-mist humidifier in the bedroom
Elevate the head of the bed slightly for older children
Saline nose drops or spray to help with congestion
Honey (for children over 1 year) can help soothe coughs
Keep child away from smoke and strong odors

infants: Use a bulb syringe to clear nasal mucus before feeding and sleeping
Saline drops before suctioning can help loosen mucus
Keep baby upright for 20-30 minutes after feeding
toddlers: Teach to blow nose gently, one nostril at a time
Offer warm liquids like chicken soup
Use honey (1-2 teaspoons) for cough relief

what_not_to_do: Do NOT give cough and cold medicines to children under 6 years
Do NOT give honey to infants under 1 year (botulism risk)
Do NOT use mentholated rubs on infants under 2 years
Do NOT give aspirin to children

vomiting_diarrhea.title: Vomiting and Diarrhea Care Guide
vomiting_diarrhea.summary: Most vomiting and diarrhea in children is caused by viral gastroenteritis ('stomach flu') and resolves within a few days.
when_to_call_911: Blood in vomit (looks red or like coffee grounds)
Child is unresponsive or very difficult to wake
Signs of severe dehydration (no tears, sunken eyes, lethargic)
when_to_call_now: Blood in stool (red or black tarry stool)
Vomiting for more than 24 hours in children under 2 years
Vomiting for more than 48 hours in older children
No wet diaper for 8 hours or no urination for 8 hours
Child refuses all fluids
Projectile vomiting in infant under 3 months
Child has severe stomach pain or pain in right lower belly
when_to_call_24_hours: Diarrhea lasting more than 1 week
Vomiting lasting more than 2-3 days
Fever with vomiting or diarrhea lasting more than 3 days
Child seems dehydrated (dry mouth, less tears, decreased urination)

rehydration.key_message: The most important treatment is preventing dehydration by replacing lost fluids.
recommended_fluids: For older children: water, diluted juice, clear broths
how_to_give_fluids: Small amounts frequently: 1-2 tablespoons every 5-10 minutes
Use a syringe, spoon, or cup for small children
Goal: 1-2 ounces per hour for infants, 2-4 ounces per hour for older children
what_to_avoid: Sports drinks (not appropriate for young children)

feeding: Restart regular diet as soon as child can tolerate it (within 12-24 hours)
Avoid fatty or spicy foods initially
BRAT diet (bananas, rice, applesauce, toast) is okay but not required

medications.note: Most medications are NOT recommended for children with vomiting/diarrhea
what_not_to_give: Anti-diarrhea medications (like Imodium) - not for children
Anti-nausea medications - only if prescribed by doctor

rash.title: Rash Care Guide
rash.summary: Rashes are common in children and usually caused by viral infections or allergic reactions. Most are not serious.
when_to_call_911: Rash with purple or red spots that don't fade when pressed (petechiae/purpura)
Rash with difficulty breathing or swelling of face/lips/tongue
Child seems very sick, lethargic, or has stiff neck with rash
when_to_call_now: Rash that spreads rapidly
Rash with high fever (above 104°F/40°C)
Rash with severe itching that is not controlled with home care
Blistering rash
Rash that looks infected (increasing redness, warmth, pus)
when_to_call_24_hours: Rash with fever lasting more than 3 days
Rash not improving after several days
Rash spreading to new areas
Concern about possible exposure to infectious disease

general_advice: Keep the area clean and dry
Avoid harsh soaps and hot baths
for_itching: Hydrocortisone cream 1% (for children over 2, or as directed by doctor)
Oral antihistamine (diphenhydramine) for severe itching - check dosing

viral_exanthem.description: Pink or red spots/bumps appearing with or after viral illness
viral_exanthem.treatment: Usually resolves on its own in 3-5 days

hives.description: Raised, itchy, red welts that come and go
hives.warning: Seek immediate care if with breathing difficulty or swelling

eczema.description: Dry, itchy, red patches often in elbow/knee creases
eczema.treatment: Moisturize frequently, avoid triggers, topical steroids if prescribed

ear_pain.title: Ear Pain Care Guide
ear_pain.summary: Ear pain is common in children, often caused by ear infections or fluid buildup.
when_to_call_911: Ear pain with stiff neck and high fever
Child is unresponsive or very difficult to wake
when_to_call_now: Severe ear pain
Ear pain with facial weakness or drooping
Bloody or pus discharge from ear
Significant swelling or redness behind the ear
Ear pain after inserting object in ear
when_to_call_24_hours: Ear pain lasting more than 2 days
Ear pain with fever
Ear pain not relieved by pain medicine
Clear or cloudy fluid draining from ear

pain_relief: Acetaminophen or ibuprofen for pain (see dosage charts)
what_not_to_do: Do not put anything in the ear (cotton swabs, drops) unless directed by doctor
Do not fly if possible during acute ear infection

emergency_signs.title: Warning Signs - When to Seek Emergency Care
always_call_911: Child is not breathing or is struggling to breathe
Child is unresponsive or very difficult to wake up
Child has purple or red spots on skin that don't fade with pressure
Severe allergic reaction with difficulty breathing or swelling of face/throat
Child is choking and cannot breathe, cry, or cough
Serious injury (head injury with loss of consciousness, suspected broken bone, deep cut)
infants_under_3_months: Very sleepy or hard to wake
